title: 105_hr1272
content:
The "Fire Administration Authorization Act of 1997" authorizes appropriations for fire prevention and control, with specific funding amounts allocated for fiscal years 1998 and 1999. Additionally, successor fire safety standards are addressed in the Act. SEC. 3. SUCCESSOR FIRE SAFETY STANDARDS. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include successor standards for various fire safety regulations. SEC. 4. TERMINATION OR PRIVATIZATION OF FUNCTIONS. The Administrator of the United States Fire Administration must notify Congress at least 60 days before terminating or transferring any significant function to a private sector entity. SEC. 5. LIMITATIONS. Prohibition of lobbying activities for funds authorized by this Act, except for communication to Congress on legislation or appropriations. Limitation on appropriations for the Administrator of the United States Fire Administration. Eligibility for awards. Eligibility for Awards: The Administrator of the United States Fire Administration will exclude individuals from grant agreements if they received non-competitive federal funds after fiscal year 1997, effective for 5 years. Exceptions exist for specific classes specified by law. The term "grant agreement" refers to a legal instrument transferring value for a public purpose authorized by US law, excluding property or services for direct US Government benefit. The Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 (15 U.S.C. 3710a(d)(1)) allows for the transfer of value for public purposes authorized by US law. SEC. 6. NOTICE.

Notice of reprogramming actions involving funds authorized by this Act must be provided to the Appropriations Committees of the House of Representatives and the Senate, as well as the Committee on Science of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate. The Administrator of the United States Fire Administration must also give notice to relevant committees before any major reorganization. 

SEC. 7. SENSE OF CONGRESS ON THE YEAR 2000 PROBLEM. SEC. 7. SENSE OF CONGRESS ON THE YEAR 2000 PROBLEM.

Congress emphasizes the need for the United States Fire Administration to address 2-digit date-related computer system issues before the year 2000. This includes assessing risks, planning for Year 2000 compliance, and creating contingency plans for critical systems. The Act emphasizes compliance with the Buy American Act for entities receiving financial assistance. It also encourages the purchase of American-made equipment. Recipients of assistance must be provided with a notice regarding this requirement. The House of Representatives passed the Act on April 23, 1997. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
